#Text=Eastern Anatolia
#Text=Eastern Anatolia
#Text=( Turkish : Doğu Anadolu ) is a region in Turkey .
#Text=It occupies the mountainous east of the country and has the harshest winters .
#Text=Cities
#Text=— town in the north , on the road to Georgia and the Turkish Black Sea coast
#Text=— old town close to Malatya
#Text=— historic town with artifacts dating back to Ottomans and to Hittites of distant past
#Text=— town on Iran ian border , hub for visiting fascinating Ishak Pasa Palace nearby , as well as climbing up Mt Ararat
#Text=— city in northwest , surrounded by mountains and lakes , and the hub for visiting wonderful old city of Harput
#Text=— biggest city of the region , near Palandöken Ski Centre
#Text=— the most remote city of the country , in the far southeastern reaches
#Text=— city in northeast , with interesting Russian architecture
#Text=— locally known as Eğin , this is a beautiful old town on the Karasu River , and is the base town for the adventure sports hotspot of the Karanlık Kanyon ( " Dark Canyon " )
#Text=— the largest city in western part of Eastern Anatolia ; a city featuring lots of parks
#Text=— town on the railroad to Tatvan/Lake Van
#Text=— on the western coast of Lake Van , eastern terminus of railway from Istanbul , with ferry connections to Van and then on to Iran .
#Text=— city on the eastern coast of Lake Van , with some remnants from Urartu civilization and some Armenian monasteries , too .
#Text=Other destinations
#Text=— the old Armenian capital
#Text=Mountain — a UNESCO World Heritage site , with statues on its summit
#Text=Understand

#Text=Covering an area in which you can fit in four Switzerland s with still some more room , but with a population of just over 6 million , Eastern Anatolia is all about lonely and vast landscapes of mountainous terrain , with occasional flat-ish plateau inflitrated inbetween .
#Text=Climate

#Text=While the daytime temperatures of around 30 °C — yet it can easily hit 40°C or more in relatively lower western parts of the region around Malatya , though — in summer make travelling in Eastern Anatolia a breeze ( especially if you have arrived from the much hotter regions of Southern and Southeastern Turkey ) , the nights are fairly chilly and it 's common for temperatures to go down as low as +12°C in late evenings , even in the hottest month of August , so pack along at least a cardigan or sweater .

#Text=Eastern Anatolia is constantly under snowcover during winter , which even shuts some non-major roads for days on end , and temperature can drop as low as a whopping -40°C — warm clothing is more essential than ever .
#Text=Talk
#Text=In the eastern and southeastern areas ( near Iran ian border and around Lake Van ) of the region , the mother tongue of most locals is Kurdish .
#Text=However most locals , especially younger ones , are also bilingual in Turkish , although heavily accented in most cases .

#Text=Local Turkish dialect spoken in northeastern section of the region ( around Erzurum , and Kars ) is far from the standard Turkish based on Istanbul dialect and is very close to Azerbaijani spoken in the neighbouring country ( to the point of being virtually identical in the easternmost parts of the region , around Iğdır close to the border with Nakhchivan ) , although the written word always uses standard Turkish orthography as is usual .
#Text=Zaza
#Text=, another Indo-Iranian language closely related to Kurdish , may also be heard in certain locales , especially in the central parts of the region around Tunceli and Bingöl .
#Text=As in Southeastern Anatolia , it is important to be cautious with whom you are smattering Kurdish or Zaza .
#Text=Trying to strike up a conversation in those languages with a Turkish official , especially one from military , can have dire consequences .
#Text=Get in
#Text=Erzurum
#Text=is the main gateway to the region with fairly frequent air , bus , and rail connections with the rest of the country .
#Text=Other secondary-major cities with airports include Malatya , and Van , both of which also has rail links with the rest of the country , and with Iran in the case of Van .
#Text=Occasionally potholed ( but getting better and wider day by day ) highways connect the region to other Turkish regions in north , south , and west ; and to Iran to east .
#Text=See
#Text=At the borderlands of various empires that existed in the vicinity during the last millenia , Northeastern Anatolia is rich in medieval and early modern sites .
#Text=The local hub is Erzurum .

#Text=The modern city is not especially historic or beautiful , but it 's the site of a citadel and two madrasahs ( Islamic academies ) , one of them built in the 13th century by the Seljuk Sultanate of Rum , decorated with turquoise tiles typical of the Seljuks , and the other dating back to the 14th century , when the area was ruled by the Ilkhanids , an offshoot of Genghis 's Mongolians who later converted to Islam .
#Text=North of Erzurum , a major highway follows the Çoruh River towards the Black Sea coast .
#Text=The local mountains are dotted by the ruins of numerous castles and churches built by the medieval Georgian kingdom .
#Text=The most impressive site is perhaps the Öşkvank Monastery in the village of Çamlıyamaç , about 100 km ( 60 mi ) from Erzurum .
#Text=Northeast from Erzurum , you will arrive at the national park covering the Allahuekber Mountains .
#Text=This was the scene of the 1914 – 15 Battle of Sarikamish , fought between Ottoman Turkey and the Russian Empire as part of the Caucasus Campaign during World War I .

#Text=Ill-prepared for the harsh winters of the area , up to 60,000 Turkish soldiers froze to death there ; annual commemorations take place in the national park , which is also known for its extensive Scots pine forests and healthy populations of wolves and bears , which are rather few in the country .
#Text=The area east of the Allahuekber Mountains was ruled by the Russian Empire for four decades before its collapse .
#Text=A notable local town is Sarıkamış , where a derelict hunting lodge built by the last czar , Nicholas II ( r. 1894 – 1917 ) , is one of the main attractions .

#Text=Nearby Kars is much more famous for its Russian heritage — stately Russian mansions line its street grid , as do beautiful mosques that had been built as Russian Orthodox or Armenian Apostolic churches .
#Text=Further east , on the high steppes over a river gorge is the evocative ruins of Ani , the medieval Armenian capital .

#Text=Southwards , at the foothills of the Mount Ararat , Turkey 's highest at 5,137 m ( 16,854 ft ) , is the town of Doğubeyazıt , near the main border crossing to Iran . İshak Pasha Palace , an amazing 17th-century palace and citadel complex on a hillside high above the town , is the main sight .
#Text=Also nearby , off the highway to Van , is the scenic Muradiye Waterfalls , which gets frozen every winter .
#Text=The rim of Lake Van , the largest lake in Turkey , is known for its ancient sites and Armenian heritage .
#Text=This is the land of the Urartu — a name that will be easily recalled the visitors of Ankara ' s Museum of Anatolian Civilizations , which has a large exhibition of fine Urartian ironwork .
#Text=The main city of the area is Van , at the eastern end of the lake .
#Text=As Tushpa , the city was the capital of the Urartu kingdom , formed by an Iron Age people .
#Text=Its castle , on a striking rocky outcrop above the lake , is not to be missed , as are numerous Urartian cuneiform inscriptions in the surrounding area .
#Text=Except for a few centuries-old buildings , Old Van , in the lakeside plains just below the castle , was heavily damaged and abandoned during World War I.

#Text=The countryside to the southeast of Van features ancient and medieval citadels , and other isolated historic and natural attractions but far more travellers head west along the southern coast of the lake to Gevaş , from where boats to the Akdamar Island can be taken .
#Text=The island is topped by one of the jewels of the region , the 10th century Cathedral of the Holy Cross , which has extensive bas reliefs of Biblical scenes .
#Text=Tatvan
#Text=is the hub for travelling around the western half of Lake Van .

#Text=Just above the town is the Mount Nemrut , a dormant volcano with a summit nearing 3,000 m ( 9,700 ft ) — higher than the mountain of the same name near Kahta to the west , better known for the statues of the ancient gods on its summit .
#Text=The
#Text=caldera has freshwater lakes inside , one of which is comfortably warm regardless the season thanks to a hot spring flowing into it , all surrounded by a birch forest .
#Text=The views over Lake Van and the surrounding area from the caldera rim are simply phenomenal .
#Text=Northeast from Tatvan , the medieval cemetery at Ahlat is known for its massive , highly elaborate headstones cut from dark volcanic rocks , in a similar fashion with the Armenian khachkars .

#Text=Many towns around the lake , including Gevaş , Ahlat , and Erciş , feature Seljuk kümbet s , cylindrical or often octogonal mausolea topped by a cone , seemingly influenced by local Armenian and Georgian architectural styles , with much stonework .
#Text=The Upper Euphrates Valley at the western half of the region is full of old towns .
#Text=Malatya
#Text=is a reasonable hub for travelling around this part of Eastern Anatolia .
#Text=While Malatya is a relatively new city by Turkish standards , there is a 19th-century mosque in downtown , as well as ( the ruins of ) a contemporary Armenian church .
#Text=A small hydropower plant , one of the oldest in the country , is also an attraction of the city , as is the park with many water features surrounding it .
#Text=Nearby Orduzu is a village of pretty single- or two-floored adobe houses with timber frames .
#Text=Far more archaeologically important , though , is the nearby Aslantepe Mound , an eastern outpost of the Hittites , a Bronze Age people often associated with Central Anatolia to the west .
#Text=A number of detailed sculptures with typically Hittite designs were excavated in the site and have been exhibited there .
#Text=West from Malatya , Darende is the site of the Somuncu Baba shrine .
#Text=Imagine a tomb of a local saint and a small adjoining mosque in a very beautifully landscaped garden , all stucked into a narrow ravine , clinging to the cliffs .
#Text=Just north of Malatya , Battalgazi is locally known as " Old Malatya " , as it was the original site of that city .
#Text=A major centre during the centuries past , it features a Seljuk-built mosque , with beautiful , if a bit worn , turquoise tiles and unique in Turkey for having an inner courtyard .
#Text=The other attractions in the town include a caravanserai and Roman -built city walls .
#Text=Across the Karakaya Dam Lake , kind of a very low-key local resort , you will arrive in Elazığ .
#Text=As with Malatya , the city was moved to its current location only in the 19th century ( so you wo n't see anything older ) , and its original site , Harput is up the hills .
#Text=Topped by a castle , the streets of Harput are lined by historic houses with stone-built ground floors and wooden upper floors .
#Text=Upriver along the Euphrates , you will arrive in Kemaliye , locally Eğin , which sits in a particularly lush valley bottom .
#Text=It is a beautiful town with many mansions , sharing a similar architectural style with those of Harput .
#Text=In the outskirts , a series of tight tunnels and passes negotiate a formidable and barren terrain high above a deep gorge .

#Text=If anywhere could be called " the beaten path " in this part of the world , that would be the trio of Harput , Kemaliye , and nearby Divriği ( in Central Anatolia ) , but that does n't mean much .
